The interpretation of the United States Constitution to include the authority of Congress to issue paper money and regulate digital currency has been addressed by various courts, including the Supreme Court of the United States and lower federal courts.

For example, in the case of Knox v. Lee (1870), the Supreme Court upheld the authority of Congress to issue paper money as a means of financing the Civil War. In this case, the Court held that the power to coin money and regulate the value thereof under Article I, Section 8 of the Constitution includes the power to issue paper money as legal tender.

In more recent cases related to digital currencies, lower federal courts have also addressed the issue of the federal government's authority to regulate digital currencies. These cases have generally upheld the authority of the federal government to regulate digital currencies and have recognized the power of Congress under Article I, Section 8 of the Constitution to regulate currency, including digital forms of currency.

While these cases do not provide a comprehensive list of all the courts that have addressed this issue, they demonstrate the recognition by the courts of the authority of Congress to issue paper money and regulate digital currencies under the Constitution.
